name: file-upload
title: File Upload
description: File Upload widget allows for multiple file selection, drag&drop support and progress monitoring. Files are uploaded via XMLHttpRequests if supported and uses iframes as fallback for legacy browsers.
note: File Upload is inspired by this css-tricks article.

browserSupport.note: * IE9 will use iFrame to post files without browser refresh and it will work only with same-orgin requests. Drag and drop falls back to just input and only one file can be selected at a time.

options.name: accept
options.description: String of mime types to limit to certain extensions for file types, i.e. '.doc,image/*'. See this resource for more info.

options.name: ajax
options.description: This is an ajax api url. If not set, File Upload will act just like a regular file input and can be embedded within a form.

options.name: auto-submit
options.description: If set to true, files will be uploaded via ajax right after file selection. It also hides an upload button.

options.name: id
options.description: Use id if you want to use events.

options.name: method
options.description: A method of the ajax request.

options.name: model
options.description: After ajax request, File Upload will return a response from the server with file paths.

options.name: multiple
options.description: If set to true, one more files are allowed to be dragged-over/selected. On IE9, user will have to upload one file at a time.

options.name: file-list
options.description: A list of selected files. Share this object with other components like <image-preview> or <text-preview>

options.name: hide-button
options.description: This could be handy if you want to submit ajax request using 'submit::file-upload' event.

options.name: text
options.description:
Allows to modify text within the component. Default values:
{action: 'Choose a file'
drag: 'or drag it here.'
selected: 'files selected'
button: 'Upload'
uploading: 'Uploading...;'
done: 'Done!'
restart: 'Upload more?'
retry: 'Try again!'}
